boardgame.name: The Heart of Amun Khonshu
boardgame.description:
From the back cover:

It all started simply enough, just like your last adventure, and perhaps even the one before that. There you were, in a tavern, when someone you'd never met before approached you with a promise of great wealth complicated only by just a little danger.

"Good people, I beseech you: Hear my story. My name is Allyn, and someone dear to me has suffered a tremendous atack upon his very soul. He now lies on the verge of death.

"As a child, I was fascinated by a story of an enchanted ruby with the power to bring a lost soul back from the dead. I have traveled far and wide in pursuit of many different and amazing treasure, but I have only recently discovered that this story may be true and that the ruby might actually exist.

"You see, many hundreds of years ago - in the region we now call the Great Desert of Ninva - there ruled a wicked man named Amun Khonshu. Some say he was a powerful sorcerer, others say he was a god. In searching for this fabled ruby, I have found that this region did not become a desert until after this vile man died. Once his vast power was taken with him into the afterlife, its horrible absence left a terrible blight upon the land.

"Regardless of the effects of his disappearance, Amun Khonshu was a murderer and a tyrant who ruled over the people of these lands by a fanatical death cult dedicated to his advancement. Fortunately, upon Amun Khonshu's death, his cult was driven underground and eventually destroyed by neighboring nations. But before the cult was vanquished, the servants of Amun Khonshu managed to preserve their leader's body and seal it away in a secret tomb, along with his vast store of ill-gotten treasure. Legend has it that they left the enchanted ruby there as well, to guide his soul back to his mortal frame.

"Good people, I believe I have found the location of this tomb, but my own band of associates was sadly not up to the task of surmounting the perils of the Ninva Desert. I beg you, please help me find the Heart of Amun Khonshu to save my friend. If you do, all of the treasure of that tomb, save the ruby, is yours -- all of it!

"What say you?"

boardgame.name: Ritual
boardgame.description:
Introduction:

Ri+Val (Ritual) is a game of strategy based on the Books of Rituals.
The books are collections of rituals, where each page is an ancient manuscript with which you can tackle your opponent.
In Ritual every player embodies the spirit of an Immortal Sorcerer who must demonstrate his magical abilities and strategic skills.
Each book is protected by 5 seals: once they are destroyed the Sorcerer can take possession of the opponent's Book:
the ultimate goal is to control as many books as possible becoming the most powerful sorcerer in History!

Setting:
Millenias ago, an ancient powerfull civilazation was at its most high evolution point. All of its society was based on the magic and spiritual power of Nature. There were five Guilds,
Earth, Fire, Water, Air and the Guil of Destiny which rulled them all with justice and equity.
One day Evok, the demon spirit of the Abyss, escaped from his century long imprisonment. He promised revenge over the ones who chained him for so long in Darkness.
Gathering all sorts of evil souls and demons he attacked with fury the Capital of that ancient world.
The flames reached the sky, floods destroyed the land and everything seeemed near to an end...
The most powerfull Sorcerers then united their powers for the final battle against Evok: after an epical fight the evil spirit was resealed in his Jail forever.
Unfortunatly, that ancient world was destined to extinction, therefore the Sorcers wrote down on books all their knowledge and magic power.
Now these books have returned to chose the future of this world: who will be the most powerfull Sorcerer?!

General Game Rules:
Every player has a book which contains 33 Rituals
Evey book is "protected" by 5 Seals (this can be read as every player has 5 life points)
The Rituals are devided in Curses, Blessings and Summonings
which use Runes to be cast in to play.
They also have Element Points and Seal points which show the
power of every single Ritual.

Every turn you have 5 Runes to use.
The Turn is divided into
1-Casting Phase:
put into play the Rituals

2-Combat Phase
fighting phase

3-Closing Phase
resolution of combat

This is the general description of the game's rules,
shortly it will be available on the website.

boardgame.name: Basic Action Super Heroes! Sci-Fi Edition
boardgame.description:
This is a Sci-Fi themed variant of the original Basic Action Super Heroes! game.

The basic mechanic is rolling 2d6 and multiplying the result by the appropriate stat (Brawn, Agility, or Mind) plus any applicable modifiers and beating a target number. Simple and easy.

Characters are built on points. While there are plenty of options here, it won't take you hours to build a character and you could jot all relevant stats down on a 3x5 index card.

This version includes guides for creating alien races. There are also rules for starship combat. Scenarios range from Victorian Steampunky Sci-Fi to Sci-Fi Fantasy to Post Apocolyptic genre.

boardgame.name: Five Star Final
boardgame.description:
This newspaper-themed board game was based on 1931 movie "Five Star Final". The game includes a large (30" x 17") and heavy board, five player tokens, 40 Service Tokens, a deck of yellow Assignment Cards, and a deck of white News Cards.

Players take Assignment Cards from the Editor that show events underway around the board. They then choose how to travel there: by foot, bus, elevated, taxi or subway. By foot is slowest but reaches everywhere; subway is fastest but can mean an additional walk to many locations.

To complete an assignment, reporters first must arrive on the spot by exact roll of either two dice or one of the two. If they fail to land on the space two turns in a row, they have missed the story and must head back to the office. However, if they stroll back, they get a chance to draw an Assignment card on any other Assignment location on which they land, getting partial or full credit for that story instead.

Players who do land on their Assignment locations must then try to draw a News Card that matches their assignments, drawing twice a turn until they do. When they do draw the right match, they normally get one Service Token, but none if sent to Rewrite, and two if labelled Front Page. Then they head back to get another assignment. First player to get five Service Tokens wins.

boardgame.name: Sword of Fire: the Battle of Lutter, 27th August 1626
boardgame.description:
After having passed most of the summer season waiting for event, Christian of Denmark decided to stir himself up and join the other part of his army to combat Tilly, left a little unmanned after having lost several detachments to guard conquered cities. His movements where to slow, and when the two armies joined battle, Tilly was probably a little superior to his opponent. Christian was unable to avoid the clash, and he suffered a defeat.

Each combat unit represents from 250 to 1500 soldiers, and it is rated, from left to right, for combat morale and movement. Each infantry strength point is around 150 men, each cavalry strength point around 80 men. Each leader is rated for Command (indicating how many activation chits that leader has) and Movement.

Each hex is about 75 meters.
Each turn is half on hour.

Contains:
6 page rules
11x17" map (in 2 8.5x11" parts)

boardgame.name: The Wreyland Serpent

From the back cover:

Instant Adventure for 4-6 characters levels 12-15

"I am Princess Athanake"

The woman who stands before you is young and beautiful, attired in gowns of the finest green velvet, and bearing with calm grace a circlet of gold upon her brow. She captures, in the slightest gesture and inflection, a porcelain perfection that you can once believed to exist only in storybooks and myth. She is a princess.

"I wish that it were under happier circumstances and calmer skies that I welcomed you to Anach, so that we might prepare a royal feast and listen to your tales in better company. Unfortunately, that is not to be, at least for now. Instead of telling tales, I fear that I must ask you to make new ones.

"Three days ago Royal Miners discovered the hidden lair of the Wreyland Serpent, a black dragon who has ravaged our lands for as long as memory allows. All but one of the men who worked there were savagely butchered by the creature."

She delicately extends a hand to one side, and a waiting courtier immediately steps forward and places a scroll within her grasp. The princess, in turn, extends it to you.

"This is a royal decree, sealed less than a quarter hour ago, giving you whatever lawful authority is necessary to prosecute our interests in this matter.

"I beg you. Deliver my people from this beast."

boardgame.name: Battlefield Evolution: Pacific War – World War Two Miniatures Rules 1944-1945
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Japan’s imperialistic ambitions to dominate the entire Pacific may seem a mad gamble when viewed from a comfortable 21st Century perspective, but it should be remembered that, in the 1940’s, empires still existed. European powers had commanded vast tracts of the Pacific region for centuries, and the British Empire remained the largest in history. On the other side of the world, Germany had dominated almost the whole of continental Europe, so the idea of powerful nations taking territory by force was an attractive idea that, today, might seem repugnant.

Despite naval actions in oceans over the globe, it was Japan’s entry into the war that truly turned hostilities into a World War. By attacking Pearl Harbour, Japan ensured the United States was put into a position whereby it could no longer remain neutral. No longer was the fighting confined to Europe and Africa, with warships trading blows overseas. Now the people of almost every continent were directly affected by war.

Ultimately, Japan failed in its gamble. Before it fell, however, it had dealt the United States a grievous blow, and all but ended the hold European countries had in the region (not least because they had their own problems back in Europe). Once forced on the defensive, Japan proved to be a terrible enemy, its people willing to fight to their last breath, ferociously resisting the advance of the Allies as its forces were gradually pushed back to the Japanese islands.

The end of the Pacific war marked the end of the Second World War as a whole, an ending that was mushroom-shaped and terrifying., leading on to a new struggle that would hold the world in its grip for the rest of the 20th Century.

This supplement for Battlefield Evolution: World at War contains army lists and new rules for the following armies, in all periods of the Pacific War.

British Army and Commonwealth
Chindits
Imperial Japanese Army
Imperial Japanese SNLF
United States Marines Corps

boardgame.name: Palast der Goldenen Tiger
boardgame.description:
(from the back of the book)

The splendid markets and impressive buildings of the city of Malrhira are known far across the borders of Tharpura - and not at last also its wise ruler, the Satrap Thyrodatus.
However, in the last Oktals a shadow has fallen on Malrhira: Heavily armed Pardir patrols tyrannise the population, and most friends and confidants of the Satrap have been incarcerated as traytors or vanished without a trace. Under these circumstances the famous fights take place, which are held in memory of the fall of a tyrant from old time. It requires some courage, but also clever heads and a strong sword arm to find out the background of this strange change - a splendid opportunity for foreign adventurers to make themselves a reputation ... or die by the attempt.

Weit über die Grenzen Tharpuras hinaus kennt man die prächtigen Märkte und beeindruckenden Bauten der Stadt Malrhira­ - und nicht zuletzt auch ihren weisen Herrscher, den Satrapen Thyrodatus.
In den letzten Oktalen aber ist ein Schatten auf Malrhira gefallen: Schwerbewaffnete Pardir-Patrouillen tyrannisieren die Bevölkerung, und die meisten Freunde und Vertrauten des Satrapen sind als Verräter eingekerkert oder spurlos verschwunden. Und unter diesen Umständen finden nun die weitberühmten Kampfspiele statt, die zur Erinnerung an den Sturz eines Tyrannen aus alter Zeit abgehalten werden. Es bedarf schon einigen Mutes, aber auch kluger Köpfe und eines starken Schwertarms, um den Hintergrund dieser merkwürdigen Veränderung herauszufinden -­ eine prächtige Gelegenheit für auswärtige Abenteurer, sich einen Ruf als Helden zu machen ... oder bei dem Versuch zu sterben.

boardgame.name: Finnish Civil War
boardgame.description:
Finnish Civil War, is a simulation game of the civil conflict in Finland in the early months of 1918. The game is for two players, one representing the recently elected government of the recently independent state (the White player) and the other the perhaps-irresistible forces of proletarian revolution (the Red Player).

The game comes in two versions:
1) a company/battalion scale one which uses a system heavily modified from the designer's previously published games Freikorps, Konarmiya and War Plan Crimson; and
2) a brigade scale one that uses fewer counters and an even more heavily modified system.

Both versions use the same map (hex grid of southern Finland, at 12 map miles/ 20 km per hex). Special units and chromy bits include: variable-strength Red and White Guard units; Armored Trains; the spring thaw that occurred midway through the war; peace negotiations, German intervention and Russian withdrawal (including the Future Guilt Clause!); General Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim; guerrillas; purges; and the Swedish Talent Agency.

Was available for free download at designer's personal webpage from end of 2009, but in October 2012 the designer concluded an agreement with Compass Games for them to publish this game in Paper Wars magazine. Compass Games has requested that the free version of the game be taken down. Both versions of the game appeared in issue #84 of the magazine, in December 2016.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 7 days
Hex: 12 miles / 20 kilometers
Units: Company to Brigade

Game Inventory:
One 17 x 22" full-color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (240 1/2" counters)
One 20-page Finnish Civil War rulebook

Solitaire Suitability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-6 hours

Note: One 6-sided die is needed for play

boardgame.name: Conflict of Heroes: Guadalcanal – El Pacífico, 1942
Conflict of Heroes: Guadalcanal – Pacifique 1942
Conflict of Heroes: Guadalcanal – The Pacific 1942
boardgame.description:
In 1942, the Japanese empire exploded across the Pacific, conquering everything before them. The only large land mass still held by the Allies was Australia, which they desperately needed as a staging area for a planned U.S. led counter-attack. The Japanese knew of the importance of Australia, but lacked the resources to conquer it, so they decided on the next best thing: Isolate Australia from the United States by building an airfield on the island of Guadalcanal, from which planes could disrupt the Allied supply lines.

The United States, ill-prepared as it was for any offensive actions, immediately attacked with the 1st Marine Division under the command of Major General Alexander A. Vandegrift, caught the Japanese by surprise and easily took control of the airfield. The Japanese 17th Army, under the command of Lt. Gen. Harukichi Hyakutake, counterattacked with an ever-increasing number of troops. For the next four months a titanic struggle took place in the air, on land and on sea as the isolated Marines and U.S. Army fought for their lives to hold their tiny perimeter around the airfield against the might of the Japanese Empire.

Conflict of Heroes: Guadalcanal – Pacific Ocean 1942 recreates this struggle on your tabletop and includes gorgeous beach and jungles maps of the South Pacific, amphibious landing craft, the USMC, Japanese Banzai Charges, night combat, and much more.

boardgame.name: Squiggle Connect
boardgame.description:
Squiggle Connect is a hilarious drawing game where players compete by changing a squiggly line into a picture. No artistic talent required . . . just your imagination!

It all starts with a roll of the dot cube and then the dots are connected by random lines using the connect cube. Once everyone has their unique squiggly line in front of them, play begins. Players have 60 seconds to transform their wavy and wacky line into a picture. They can be as simple or detailed as they want. When time is up, each player explains their drawing to the other players. This is where you may fall over laughing as you listen to some real nonsense! Once each player has had chance to explain what they drew, voting begins. Each player votes on only one other players drawing using a voting card.

The voting cards offer either a descriptive praise or a nuance of criticism such as "put that in a doggie bag" or "a monkey can do better". Each card also has a point value and players give them to each other based on their picture and description. It’s hysterical!

SQUIGGLE Connect recently won a National Parenting Publications Gold Award!

(from manufacturer's website)

boardgame.name: Pizza Party
boardgame.description:
(publisher blurb):
A mouth-watering way to learn fractions! This set of 12 realistic 12" (30. 5cm) pizzas is the "main course" upon which eight different fraction games are based. Includes 12 cardboard pizzas cut into halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, eighths, ninths, twelfths, and sixteenths, plus two spinners and an activity sheet. Comes in a sturdy pizza parlor box! For two to six players.

(from box front):
Pizza Party Includes:
- 2 spinners
- Activity Sheet with 8 Games
- 59 Full-Color Fraction Pizza Pieces

Players Will:
- Identify halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, eights, ninths, twelfths, and sixteenths
- Identify fractional parts of the whole
- Match fractional notation to concrete models
- Identify equivalent fractions and fractional parts
- Subtract fractional parts from a whole and other fractions

For 2-6 players
Grades 1-6

(description of the 8 games from the activity sheet):
1. Pizza Cover-Up
Skill/Purpose: Identifying the fractional parts that make up a whole.
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to cover a pizza with pizza pieces.

2. Pizza Play-Off
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying the fractional parts that make up a whole.
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to complete your pizza, with no overlapping pieces.

3. Pizza Pickup
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models.
Goal: The goal is to be the player with the most pieces after eight turns.

4. Penny a Pair
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying equivalent fractions/fractional parts.
Goal: The goal is to be the player with the most points after three rounds of play.

5. Fraction Line-Up
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying equivalent fractions/fractional parts
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to have one pizza piece of each size: 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/6, 1/8, 1/9, 1/12, and 1/16.

6. Pizza Patch
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying fractions that are even parts or multiples of another fraction.
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to have two pizzas in a winnings pile.

7. Undercover
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying equivalent fractions/fractional parts.
Goal: The goal is to be the player with the most points after 20 rounds of play.

8. Empty the Pan
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying equivalent fractions/fractional parts; subtracting fractional parts from a whole/other fractional parts.
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to have no part of a pizza left.

boardgame.name: Monster & Treasure Assortment: Levels One - Three
boardgame.description:
From the back cover:

This Monster and Treasure Assortment (Levels One to Three) is one of a set and is designed as a playing aid for Dungeons & Dragons. By using the assortment lists, game judges can generate any number of appropriate monsters or treasure by simply rolling dice - thus saving time in play and preparation.

From the front cover:

This set contains lists of 300 monsters, 300 treasures, treasure storage/guarding/hiding modes, and complete instructions for using the assortment to fill in partially stocked or newly encountered dungeon levels.

From the introduction:

This assortment of monsters and treasures by dungeon level is designed to answer two needs. First, the package provides the Dungeon Master with a ready matrix of encounters when his players are exploring a dungeon encountered in a Wilderness Adventure. Second, and more important, these assorted monsters and treasures are aimed at making the DM's task a lighter one when it comes to readying the major dungeon in which most of his players' Underworld adventures will take place

boardgame.name: Nasty, Brutish and Short
boardgame.description:
From the Back Cover:

The Orcs of Hârn

The Gargun (also called orcs and Foulspawn) reside in the high mountainous areas of Hârn, where they squabble, maim, kill, and cannibalize each other, or any other species they encounter. The book provides details on Gargun culture, maps of four orc colonies, and six related adventure scenarios.

Bwaft
A natural cave complex situated high in rugged mountains. After centuries of relative peace, the Gargun of Bwaft find themselves involved in a vicious war with the nearby Gargun of Huxuth. "A Walk Among Tombstones" involves the players in this war, while "Dead of Night" provides them the chance to enrich themselves at the expense of Bwaft's inhabitants.

Ejatus
A cave complex with Araki (small orc) population rules by a Khanu (great orc) elite. These Khanu are highly-organized and dangerous, as anyone involved in the "Dance at the Slaughterhouse" scenario will soon discover.

Fana
A rich silver mine seized by Gargun six centuries ago, and still held by them despite dozens of attempts at recapture by the dwarves of Azadmere. The orcs of Fana traditionally skirmish with nearby orc colonies, and are always a menace to traverler. "The Last Worst Hope" deals with another dwarven attempt to retake Fana

Korego
The oldest and largest Gargun colony on Hârn. The orcs of Korego have a long history of conflict with both the local human tribesmen and merchant caravans. "We Deal in Steel" is a mystery involving arms-running. "To Live and Die in Korego" gives the players a rescue mission in which some things are not what they appear.

boardgame.name: Super Sadistic Advanced Empire Builder
boardgame.description:
Empire Builder is a classic crayon-rail game by Mayfair, with many followups now available. The core idea of Empire Builder is that players to draw their train routes over a map of the United States. Players start with enough money to build short lengths of track, and by running their trains and delivering loads to various cities acquire more cash to expand their networks.

Super Sadistic Advanced Empire Builder (SSAEB) is an improved and much more challenging version of the base game. Numerous changes have been made: the payoffs on the contract cards have been lowered, the event cards are changed to be much more challenging, two new train types are added, and upgrade costs are increased.

By modifying the basic Empire Builder game with this expansion set, players will have a more challenging and longer game, but one that is more satisfying for hard-core gamers. SSAEB is for die-hard Empire Builder fans only!

boardgame.name: Exobichos
boardgame.description:
From the Back of the Book:

Since the sheller started the space discovery, we know we are not alone in the void, and that it's inhabited by a lot of beings ranging from a microscopic scale to the size of a planet.

Exobichos is a supplement for EXO that describes some of these creatures the players can meet in the spacial voyages. It includes races from distant and very different places in the universe. Some of them dwelling in spacial stations, in spacecrafts; others live in planets, but their physiology or the intervention of third-party creatures have spread them from one place to another; and some others, lived in the void, contradicting what the shellers think. Each of the description of the creatures include ideas for encounters or adventures and how they behave so all the possible situations can be solved.


Desde que los sheller iniciaron la exploración del espacio, sabemos que no estamos solos en el vacío, y que existen multitud de seres desde microscópicos a seres del tamaño de un planeta, algunos de ellos pacíficos y otros hostiles.

Exobichos es un suplemento para EXO 3464 que da a conocer algunas de esas criaturas que los jugadores podrán encontrarse en sus viajes espaciales. Pretende incluir razas dispares geográficamente y variedad de animales de diversas zonas del espacio. Algunos habitan en estaciones orbitales, en el interior de naves espaciales; otros habitan en planetas, pero su fisiología o la mano de terceras criaturas los ha llevado de un rincón de la galaxia a otro; y otros, a pesar de la original creencia sheller, habitan en el mismo vacío del espacio. Cada una de las entradas incluyen ideas de encuentros y aventuras con reglas sobre el comportamiento de las criaturas para resolverlos.

boardgame.description:
User summary:
The players in the shoes of Indiana Jones trying to collect treasures found in various parts of the world, moving through cards and dice.
The game map divides the world into 5 zones. The players depart from North America, their base, and move on other continents where they are hidden treasures to find.
On every continent there are 3 decks of cards and the last of each deck is a treasure that can be real or false in 2 cases out of three.
The goal of the game is, therefore, to discard the cards placed over the treasure to get to the bottom of the pile and earn the trophy.
The cards are discarded throwing the dice and passing score on the card in various skills, if it not succeeds, the card remains in place.
The more cards you discard the more your skills will increase.
When discovered 4 treasures will be turned into points and the player with most points is the winner.

The entire route is divided into 25 fractions by 10 km each. Players will proceed on the track throwing the dice, whose numbers indicate the gear on the vehicle, 6 indicates a stop (not moving).
Before you start you have put along the track the employees to pit which will, to player who stops in the vicinity, the chances of mechanical failure to his bike.
The "Campionato Mondiale di Motociclismo"will be held in several Grands Prix each of which will be ongoing in the 125cc category (will be held at 1 lap), 350cc (to be played in 2 turns) and 500cc (to be played in 3 rounds).

boardgame.name: Ach Du Lieber Biber
Allez les castors!
Vandfaldet: Bævere på tømmersejlads
boardgame.description:
In Ach Du Lieber Biber, beavers are surfing the waves of the icy river towards the waterfall, but while they do so, they have to beware of the floating junk and other surfers. The player who lets the fewest beavers tip over the waterfall wins the game.

In more detail, the players place the water cylinders on the river and randomly organize the surfing beavers and junk markers on top of them. They take turns rolling a "surfing die" to determine whether they have to progress the water level, with the aid of a wooden lodge across the river, towards the edge of the waterfall.

boardgame.name: Scoutspelet
boardgame.description:
This is a pretty blatant (and surely unlicensed) ripoff of Trivial Pursuit.

Everything in the game revolves around scouting. The categories are "Lord & Lady Baden-Powell", "International", "Events and places", "Swedish history and now", and "Literature and misc". Players roll dice to move pawns around the board and ask questions related to the category-space upon which they land. The goal of the game is to get point-pieces by landing on the prime space for the category and correctly answering a question in that category. The goal is to get point-pieces in all of the categories and then answer a final quesion from a category chosen by the opponents.

boardgame.name: Harbinger
boardgame.description:
A cooperative or competitive fantasy role-playing board game, the goal of which is to bring about or stop the Armageddon that will destroy the kingdom. The alignment of the characters chosen determines if the players will fight for or against the Great Evil that threatens to destroy the land.

Players explore the modular map board, revealing tiles as they go. Gameplay is primarily driven through adventure cards in which monsters are fought, treasure is found, quests are solved, and clues are uncovered that can narrow down the identity of the Great Evil. The climax of the game occurs when the identity of the Great Evil is revealed and the final battle is fought which will determine the fate of the Kingdom.

boardgame.name: Fibonacci's Trump
boardgame.description:
Fibonacci's Trump is a basic trump/trick-taking card game.

Collect tricks through playing cards depending on the color that is led, using the trump color when able. Points are determined by the symbols on the cards: the number of the symbols that is the same as the Symbol Indicator collected determines how many points you are awarded each round.

Scoring uses Fibonacci's numbers... so the more symbols you collect, the better off you are.

First player to 144 wins.

Mutant R.Y.M.D takes place in our solar system in the year of 2192, in a high technologic reality where man no longer is alone - a dark and destructive force, the Evil, has manifested itself in the outer limits of the solar system to destroy the human society. With hordes of undead legions of twisted beings, with dark technology, mysterious mental forces and malicious infiltrators in the corporations committees, it strives to the center of the solar system to suffocate the sun and enslave humanity.

The world of 2192 is a grateful breeding ground for the Evil's message. In the bottom of society terror, crime and madness thrive even without the intervention of the Evil's cultists. Eternal wars between the corporates is fought in Mercury's underground worlds, in Venus' black ocean depths, on ice cold polar caps and in damp jungles, on Mars' burning plains and in Uranus' gas landscapes.

This is a world for the strong, the faithful, the proud and the honourable. This is a world for heroes.

boardgame.name: Der Mueller
boardgame.description:
From the back of the box:

Nestled deep in the Black Forest of Bavaria lay the town of Shoental. Although the villagers worked hard, the village remained in poverty, because the domination of the dragon Gruenaugen. Gruenaugen demanded half of all goods produced by the village, or the villagers would face destruction from the dragon's wrath. Many a young lad had set forth to slay the dragon, never to return.

The young town miller (der Mueller) spent many hours thinking about the plight of his town. He knew that previous attempts to destroy the dragon by force had been fruitless. He also knew that Gruenaugen loved games, as all dragons feel they are intellectually superior. He invented a game that only the cleverest would win and confronted the dragon with a deal: freedom of the village if der Mueller won, or enslavement of der Mueller if Gruenaugen won. Gruenaugen, feeling he was superior, naturally accepted.

Der Mueller facest the hardest test of his life but overwhelmed the dragon with his strategy and won. Der Mueller returned to the village a hero. Gruenaugen was never seen again.

A strategy game for two players. The object of the game is to capture 5 of your opponent's gems. Each player starts with 8 gems and tries to complete trios to capture theur opponent's gems by placing their gems on the board during phase one, sliding their gems during phase two, and picking up and moving their gems during phase three.

Re-Implements:

Nine Men's Morris

boardgame.name: Dédalo
boardgame.description:
In this game two armies clash and the only thing that will discourage them is the fact of losing their king in battle. All the king’s men will fight to death for him, regardless of the fact that even the king is a fierce fighter.
This last battle takes place in a very strange land, long tunnels that are always changing to confuse anyone that wanders in them.

With similar mechanics as in “NiMeMo” you have to move your army around the board and try to eliminate your opponent’s pieces by blocking them.
As soon as you eliminate the other’s king you win.

Dédalo (in Spanish) comes from Daedalus. In Greek mythology Daedalus was a skilful craftsman and artisan. The Labyrinth on Crete was created by him.

boardgame.description:
English rules available.
http://legalalien.sakura.ne.jp/wiki/?Tabletop+Wargaming/Shin...

On June 8th, 1864, in Kyoto, there was a very famous sword-action between Shinsengumi and Kinnoh-rohshi. Yes, it was Ikedaya.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ikedaya_Incident

It was rumored that the most radical group of Kinnoh-rohshi had planned to kidnap Komei-emperor from Kyoto while they set up fires around Kyoto-city.
Shinsengumi, the patrol group hired by Edo-bakuhu decided to assault the Kinnoh-rohshi's meeting before the final moment. They found the meeting at Ikedaya.

This is a small postcard game. It was distributed on A-game shop's yearend-yearopening campaign between 2009 and 2010.
Basically this game uses the same game engine as 47 Ronin. Each player take action by one of his stack alternatively. Each stack can move and then fight to adjacent enemy stack. This is chess-like puzzle movement. A goes to attack B to open the path. But, the enemy moves C to defend the path just opened. And so on.
Also, if you have issue #1 of Wargame Japanese History, you can use counters from Shinsengumi Chronicle for this game.

Though this is a small game, it is filled with puzzle-like tactics and excitement of swordplay.

updated
This game is reprinted as a second game of Wargame Japanese History #27.

boardgame.name: Isla Dorada
黄金の島イスラ・ドラーダ
boardgame.description:
In the middle of the 1930s, an expedition of treasure hunters crashes its zeppelin in the middle of an unknown and mysterious island where legends tell that several old and powerful civilizations have left many sumptuous treasures.

Each player is one of these brave explorers who joined the expedition with old maps giving clues on where some of these treasures can be found. However, it is clear that the land is barely known and dangerous, so, all explorers decide to travel together, in one solid group by hiring beasts of burden and exotic items in the native villages while trying to avoid the many dangers of the inhospitable land of Isla Dorada...

Which one of these brave explorers will find the most valuable treasures, avoid the numerous curses and accomplish it's rewarding destiny?

In Isla Dorada, players will have to move a unique pawn portraying the expedition of explorers. Each player will collect cards of different kinds (movements, actions, destinations, curses, destinies, bonus or malus cards) and will have to build the best hands turn after turn (time is limited to a certain number of game turns) to be able to chose the expedition destinations in a succession of bids and negotiations. Doing so, the players will try to put their hands on treasures while avoiding their cursed destinations and trying to block other player's objectives.

The very easy rules can be learned in a few minutes whilst the rich and elegant game play assure an always renewed experience.

boardgame.name: Cubes
boardgame.description:
From the Game's Introduction:

Roleplaying at the Office

Tangibles

Pencils and paper and a standard deck of playing cards without Jokers. I recommend a deck of cards with a corporate logo. If you really want, you could make a poker deck with business cards and some markers.

Meeting Prep

Your Employee possesses three Assets which have point values. You get three points to divide among them (zero being a valid Asset).

Each of these Assets has a countering trait, called a Liability. Each Liability's value is always (4 - countering Asset).

Issues

To start, you grab five cards. You can never have more than five cards in your hand at one time. If you are told to draw more cards, you discard cards of your choice down to five.

There is no GM. This is simply a game of Employees trying to stay sane and under the radar of upper management. In fact, an Employee can't even lose her job unless she quits or does something absolutely drastic and strange. She'll most likely keep getting demoted until she's stuck in the basement with leveraged hardware from the 80's.

Whoever has the best hand gets to introduce the first Issue to the Employees. Try something simple at first, like a broken printer. The winner's Hand is placed face up in the center of the table. Everyone else discards their Hands.

Starting with the person on the winner's left, and proceeding clockwise, each Player concocts some method to solve the Issue. Friendly and cordial groups may ignore turns and simply freeform roleplay until a good solution is found.

When you have a solution, decide which Asset or Liability best fits your approach. What you do next depends on whether you are using an Asset or Liability.

Toe-to-Toe Nuclear Combat with the Rooskies
boardgame.description:
This is it, Boys, we're going in...

The “Go Code” has been received and the war plan decoded; it is time to turn your B-52 into Soviet air space, and head for your primary target. You’ve got 50,000 lbs. of fuel, two H-bombs, a crew looking to you for leadership, and a mission that your country needs you to fulfill.

Toe-to-Toe Nu’klr Combat with the Rooskies is a fast-playing solitaire game. You decide the payload, pick your targets and must then challenge the Soviet Union's defenses.

SAMs (surface-to-air missiles) and Soviet Air Defense fighter/ interceptors will find you as you cross “The Big Board.” Events will relentlessly dog you and your crew as the fate of America, even the world, rests on your shoulders. A single mission can be accomplished in about 15 minutes, or take an hour for the whole campaign game. Take a darkly humorous trip in a less-than-serious game exploding with atomic fun.

boardgame.name: Gettysburg: The Wheatfield
Tattered Flags: Game #1
boardgame.description:
Microbadges:


Tattered Flags is a series of Kriegspiel-style historical miniatures/board game depicting battles of the American Civil War (1861-1865). In this first game in the series, each player controls a Union or Confederate force at the Battle of Gettysburg, struggling for The Wheatfield on July 2nd, 1863. Gettysburg: The Wheatfield was carefully crafted to introduce players to system basics of organization, events, maneuver, fire and morale, with future games in this series promising to expand the detail and accuracy of the Tattered Flags system.

Since many players do not have the time, funds or eyesight to paint armies of miniature figures, Tattered Flags comes with colorful cardboard counters, called “Stands” (in the vernacular of miniatures gaming). These games also use a printed battlefield game map in lieu of miniature trees, hills, buildings, etc. Feel free to substitute miniature figures if desired!

There are three scenarios included in Gettysburg: The Wheatfield, each with its own Order of Battle (OOB), Special Rules, Turn Length and Victory Condition. The first scenario is introductory in complexity and is used when someone is first learning and playing the game. The second scenario is the historical scenario depicting the actual fighting that occurred during the afternoon of July 2nd. The final scenario is a dramatic, “what-if” meeting engagement battle.

Game Data:
Complexity: 5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 7 on a 9 scale
Scale: 1 inch = 50 yards; each Stand is approximately 150 men or 3-4 cannon; each turn represents a variable amount of time, perhaps 15 to 20 minutes or so

Game Components:
• One 12 page color rules booklet with lots of illustrated examples

• 8 color, die-cut 5/8" x 1.25" Leader pieces
• 1 beautiful, full color game map
• 20 Event cards
• 2 Player Aid sheets
• 1 Game Turn track
• 1 Movement measuring tool
• 1 Combat measuring tool

boardgame.name: Heavy Metal
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

The Heavy Metal roleplaying game box set contains everything needed to start playing. It includes empty character sheets and three books:

- "Style de jeu et scénarios" covers the game background, the rules system and scenarios. The game system is rather simple (stats multiplied by a skill level give a percentage change of success). The background describes a dystopian near-future society, where the rich nations of the north live off the resources of the impoverished south and the northern citizens, brainwashed by the omnipresent entertainment Networks live in xenophobic fear of "Southern Terrorists". Characters can either be U.R.C. (Unité de Répression Cybernétique), robotic cops who are judge, jury and executioners, or "Egarés" (the Lost), rebels using their meager resources trying to escape URCs and uncover the truth behind the mysterious Hopson Plan.
The book includes 4 scenarios, "London Leatherboys", "Twist & Shoot", "Bad Religion" and "Le Père Noêl est une ordure".

- "Les Egarés" focuses on the Lost. The book contains character and group creation rules (players create their character as well as the group they belong to, its ideology, financial resources, outside contacts, safe houses...) , a presentation of several rebel groups (ecowarriors, neofascists, hackers, TV show hooligans, cultists, communists...) and a list of equipment (guns, vehicles, broadcasting equipment...)

- "Les U.R.C." describes the Cybernetic Repression Units. It includes chapter about character creation (type chassis, organic or cybernetic brain, choice of software...), roleplaying tips for U.R.C. characters, a description of laws and justice in the Northern Block, and details about the Hopson Plan.

boardgame.name: Courts & Corsets
boardgame.description:
From the Game's Introduction:

Premise

Courts & Corsets seeks to reproduce the intrigue involved in such films as Amadeus and Dangerous Liasons. The goal of the players is to collectively tell a tragic and melodramatic story.

Bidding

The rules of Courts & Corsets rely entirely on a bidding process, by which players are able to influence play with an ever-dwindling resource. In this game, the tokens used for bidding are called Crowns no matter what physical piece is actually used during play. You may use any type of tokens to bid with, provided all players possess the ability to hide their tokens during a bid.

When a bid is called for, the bidding players must secretly select a number of Crowns from their available cache. Once all bidding players have done so, all must fairly display their amount. The highest bidder is considered the winner, and all Crowns bid by winner and losers are discarded (and are unavailable to the players until their caches are legally replenished). Ties are broken by the winning players conducting a second bid, or however many more bids are required to achieve a single winner.

If a situation arises where levels of triumph are needed, the player with the highest bid obtains the best goal, descending bids until the lowest bid achieves the worst result. Ties during these bids are resolved as aforementioned.

From the publisher:

The Blue Rose Narrator's Journal is a 35-page PDF designed to assist narrators in planning and organizing their campaigns and adventures. Packed with page after page of forms, the Narrator's Journal is custom-designed to make creating narrator characters, creatures, organizations, and adventures easier.

The forms in this PDF include:

Major Narrator Characters: Three pages on which you can record not only important game information but also details about the character's relationships -- to both the player character heroes and other narrator characters in the campaign -- and roleplaying notes, memorable appearances in the campaign, and minions or servants of the character.
Locations: Map out important locations in the campaign, prepare encounters, and record important events on two pages.
Shadowgates: Keep track of the shadowgates in your campaign, including their locations, appearances, and player knowledge of the gates.
Adventure Outline: Plan each encounter, the highs and lows, and important details of an upcoming adventure.
Adventure/Narrator Review: With this form the players can provide the narrator with feedback so that the narrator can learn what his players like and don?t like about the campaign. This form can be invaluable in steering a campaign in a direction that will make everyone happy.


Plus many more forms, including pages designed for creating new arcana, creatures, weapons, feats, and almost anything else you?ll want to add to your Blue Rose campaign.

boardgame.name: Catchup
Ketchup
boardgame.description:
Catchup is a simple abstract game with a devilish dynamic. The goal is to have the largest group of stones on the board when the board is full of stones, but as you get closer to winning, your opponent gets more powerful. Whereas most stone-placement games are about position, Catchup is about timing, position, and the interplay between them.

Definitions:

1. Group – a set of connected, like-colored stones on the board. A single stone is also considered a group.

2. Score - your score is the number of stones contained in your largest group. At the beginning of the game, both players' scores are set to 1

Rules:

1. One player owns the white stones and the other owns the black. White begins by placing 1 stone on any empty space.

2. From then on, starting with black, players take turns. On your turn, you may place 1 or 2 stones, or up to 3 if your opponent's score increased on their last turn and is, at the beginning of your turn, greater than or equal to your score.

3. After taking your turn, if your score has changed, move your pawn to the corresponding spot on the scoring track.

4. The game ends when the board is full. The player with the largest group wins. If the players’ largest groups are the same size, compare their second-largest groups, and so on, until you come to a pair which aren’t the same size. Whoever owns the larger of the two wins.
